title: 1  Introduction
text: This site contains the course notes for an informal one-semester seminar on category theory at CSU East Bay.

title: 2  Partially Ordered Sets
text:
2.1 The “Divides” Relation
For example, \(3\) divides \(6\) since \(3 \cdot 2 = 6\), and \(-5\) divides \(10\) since \(-5 \cdot 2 = 10\).
This is called reflexivity, and we say that \(\mid\) is reflexive because it satisfies this property. For all that follows, we denote by \(\mathbb{N}\) the natural numbers, consisting of the non-negative integers \(0, 1, 2, \dots\). Take special care to notice that we are including zero in this set.1 It will soon be apparent why we do this.
Another important note about the divides relation

title: 2  Partially Ordered Sets
text:
2.2 Defining Posets
Let \(\preccurlyeq\) denote a partial order relation.

title: 2  Partially Ordered Sets
text:
Let \(m\) and \(n\) be integers. We say \(m\) divides \(n\), and we write \(m \mid n\) if there exists an integer \(q\) such that \(mq = n\).



Exercise 2.1 Show that for any integer \(a\) we have \(a \mid a\).




Exercise 2.2 Show that for natural numbers \(a\) and \(b\), if \(a \mid b\) and \(b \mid a\), then \(a = b\).



Solution

If \(a \mid b\), then there exists a natural number \(k_1\) such that \(a k_1 = b\). Similarly, \(b \mid a\) implies there exists a natural number \(k_2\) such that \(b k_2 = a\). Hence, \(b = a k_1 = b k_1 k_2\). Thus, \(b (1 - k_1 k_2) = 0\). Then either \(b = 0\) or \(k_1 = k_2 = 1\).


Exercise 2.3 Show that if \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) are integers, and \(a \mid b\) and \(b \mid c\), then \(a \mid c\).

title: 2  Partially Ordered Sets
text: This differs from another convention that excludes zero, which you may be used to.↩︎
